p: Ensure that encryption is used to protect all sensitive data transmitted over the network.
Because network traffic can be easily eavesdropped or modified by attackers, passing sensitive data over the network is prone to a host of attacks, including data theft and data manipulation.

When an application transmits sensitive data over the network, it is necessary to ensure that it is encrypted to protect the data from being read or modified in transit. To ensure this, follow the steps outlined below:

Search for hyperlinks leading to non-TLS resources. Review application code and look for hyperlinks starting with "http://" - such hyperlinks lead to resources, which are not secured by TLS. Make sure that non-TLS hyperlinks are not used to navigate between pages that handle sensitive data.

Identify sensitive information. Sensitive data is any information that is kept secret and should be disclosed only to authorized parties. Common examples of sensitive data include, but are not limited to, names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card and other financial information, passwords and private keys. Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information. Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data. Sensitive data can be defined as follows:

Verify that sensitive data is securely transmitted. Ensure that your application transmits sensitive data in a secured fashion. Verify that your application encrypts the data using encryption or hashing and encrypts the communication link:
Encrypting application data: Your application securely transforms its application data before transmitting it over the network:

Hashing: Hashing is a one-way mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a non-retrievable way. If your application uses hashing as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:

Encryption: Encryption is a mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a retrievable way. If your application uses encryption as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:
Encrypting the communication links: Check if your application's communication links are properly secured.
Use the following steps to protect sensitive data over the network:

Identify sensitive information. Sensitive data is any information that is kept secret and should be disclosed only to authorized parties. Common examples of sensitive data include, but are not limited to, names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card and other financial information, passwords and private keys. Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information. Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data. Sensitive data can be defined as follows:

Choose an appropriate protection mechanism. Choosing the appropriate protection mechanism may depend on various conditions: purpose of the sensitive data, role of the other network party, infrastructure and supported technologies. Because sensitive data must be encrypted when in transit, there are two strategies, to encrypt the communication channel or to encrypt the application data:

Encrypt the communication channel: Depending on the current infrastructure and the other network party, it is possible to encrypt the connections using Java's crypto library or any technologies supported by the remote party.

Encrypt the application data: If your application's communication channels cannot be encrypted, encrypt the application data. Hashing or encryption should be used when protecting the application data. Use hashing if the application data will be used only for comparison purposes. Use encryption if the application data will be retrieved at a later stage.

If hashing is used, choose a longer salt, 16 or more bits. In the case that the produced hash is compromised, longer salts make it more difficult for an attacker to gain access to the sensitive data. If your application uses randomly generated salt, make sure that your application encrypts the random salt and stores it into a configuration file. Always use SecureRandom and not Random to generate the salt. Example of using SecureRandom to generate a random salt:

Choosing a strong hashing algorithm is also important. Stronger algorithms prevent multiple unique pieces of data from producing identical hash values. The current recommendation is to use SHA-256 or stronger.

Use encryption if the application data will be retrieved at a later stage.Use symmetric encryption if and only if your application is the only entity that will access the encrypted data. Use a key size of 265-bit or higher and AES for symmetric encryption.Use public/private key encryption if the data will be accessed by two or more parties. Use a key size of 2048-bit or higher and RSA for public/private key encryption. Public/private key encryption allows your application to share sensitive data with multiple entities without disclosing its own encryption key.
Apply the appropriate protection mechanism. Evaluate the code and determine the places where sensitive data is transmitted. Apply the established protection mechanism at each location.
Note: PCI DSS requirements state that all sensitive data must be encrypted before being sent over the network or be sent over an encrypted channel.

The following code authenticates a user based on a username and password. The supplied credentials are compared to the credentials stored in the backend database. Unfortunately, the credentials are transmitted in plaintext and could be stolen if the network is compromised.

The following code validates the user based on a given username and password. It uses the user's valid email address and a random salt to encrypt the user's password before comparing the username and the produced digest against the data stored in the backend database. Therefore, the password is encrypted before being transmitted over the network and is protected from being compromised.
ol:
Search for hyperlinks leading to non-TLS resources. Review application code and look for hyperlinks starting with "http://" - such hyperlinks lead to resources, which are not secured by TLS. Make sure that non-TLS hyperlinks are not used to navigate between pages that handle sensitive data.
    
    
      
        Identify sensitive information. Sensitive data is any information that is kept secret and should be disclosed only to authorized parties. Common examples of sensitive data include, but are not limited to, names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card and other financial information, passwords and private keys. Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information. Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data. Sensitive data can be defined as follows:
      
        Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with others. 
        Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application. 
        Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users
      
      
      
    
    
      
        Verify that sensitive data is securely transmitted. Ensure that your application transmits sensitive data in a secured fashion. Verify that your application encrypts the data using encryption or hashing and encrypts the communication link:
      
        
          
            Encrypting application data: Your application securely transforms its application data before transmitting it over the network:
          
            
              
                Hashing: Hashing is a one-way mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a non-retrievable way. If your application uses hashing as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:
              
                
                  Salt: Your application generates its salt using the SecureRandom class. 
                
                  Function: Your application uses SHA-256, SHA-384 or SHA-512 as its hash function. 
                
                  Invocation: Your application invokes the Cipher.doFinal method to perform the hashing procedure. 
                
                  Clean-up: Your application securely cleans-up all instances of the sensitive data after the hashing procedure has been completed. 
              
            
            
              
                Encryption: Encryption is a mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a retrievable way. If your application uses encryption as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:
              
                
                  Encryption Key: Your application's encryption keys are securely stored inside your application's key store.  
                
                  Function: Your application uses AES, 3DES, or any other strong symmetric encryption function. 
                
                  Invocation: Your application invokes the Cipher.init and Cipher.doFinal methods to perform the encryption procedure. 
                
                  Clean-up: Your application securely cleans-up all instances of the sensitive data and their encryption keys after the encryption procedure has been completed. 
              
            
          
        
        
          
            Encrypting the communication links: Check if your application's communication links are properly secured.

blockquote: public static byte[] generateSalt() throws NoSuchAlgorithmException{      // Note that salt is declared as private static byte[] and is      // initialized to null.      if (salt == null)      {            SecureRandom srand = SecureRandom.getInstance("SHA1PRNG");                          salt = new byte[4];            srand.nextBytes(salt);      }       return salt;}

public String hashCredentials(char[] pass, byte[] salt)      throws GeneralSecurityException, IOException{      MessageDigest md;      byte[] tempPass;      byte[] digest;            md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-512");      //Convert char[] to byte[]      tempPass = new byte[pass.length];      for (int i = 0; i < pass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = (byte)pass[i];      }      md.update(tempPass);      md.update(salt);      digest = md.digest();      md.reset();      //Clean tempPass      for (int i = 0; i < tempPass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = 0;      }       return new String(digest);}

try{      // The application produces a hash based on the sensitive data      userEmail = MyApp.getEmailForUser(user);      passDigest = encryptCredentials(userEmail, pass, salt);}catch (GeneralSecurityException gse){      // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms      return false;}catch (IOException ioe){      // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms      return false;}// The application stores the hashed sensitive data into the databaseConnection cn = MyApp.getDBConnection();PreparedStatement st = cn.prepareStatement("select login_attempts from myappUsers"                                        + " where user = ? and pass = ?;");st.setString(1, user);st.setBytes(2, passDigest);ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery();
public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass){      // Query the credential store with the provided credentials      ...}

public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass){       ...       // Encrypt the credentials      try      {            userEmail = MyApp.getEmailForUser(user);            passDigest = encryptCredentials(userEmail, pass, salt);      }      catch (GeneralSecurityException gse)      {            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms            return false;      }     catch (IOException ioe)      {            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms            return false;      }       // Query the credential store and execute the rest of the authentication steps      ...}public static byte[] encryptCredentials(String email, char[] pass, byte[] salt)      throws GeneralSecurityException, IOException{      MessageDigest md;       byte[] tempPass;      byte[] rawKey;      // Generate encryption key      md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-512");      md.update(email.getBytes("UTF-8"));      md.update(salt);      rawKey = md.digest();      md.reset();      SecretKeySpec skeySpec = new SecretKeySpec(rawKey, "AES");      // Set up cipher      Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");      cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, skeySpec);      // Convert char[] to byte[]      tempPass = new byte[pass.length];      for (int i = 0; i < pass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = (byte)pass[i];      }      // Encrypt password      byte[] encrypted = cipher.doFinal(tempPass);            //Clean tempPass      for (int i = 0; i < tempPass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = 0;      }      return encrypted;}

public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass){      // Query the credential store with the provided credentials      ...}

public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass){       ...       // Encrypt the credentials      try      {            userEmail = MyApp.getEmailForUser(user);            passDigest = encryptCredentials(userEmail, pass, salt);      }      catch (GeneralSecurityException gse)      {            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms            return false;      }     catch (IOException ioe)      {            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms            return false;      }       // Query the credential store and execute the rest of the authentication steps      ...}public static byte[] encryptCredentials(String email, char[] pass, byte[] salt)      throws GeneralSecurityException, IOException{      MessageDigest md;       byte[] tempPass;      byte[] rawKey;      // Generate encryption key      md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-512");      md.update(email.getBytes("UTF-8"));      md.update(salt);      rawKey = md.digest();      md.reset();      SecretKeySpec skeySpec = new SecretKeySpec(rawKey, "AES");      // Set up cipher      Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");      cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, skeySpec);      // Convert char[] to byte[]      tempPass = new byte[pass.length];      for (int i = 0; i < pass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = (byte)pass[i];      }      // Encrypt password      byte[] encrypted = cipher.doFinal(tempPass);            //Clean tempPass      for (int i = 0; i < tempPass.length; i++)      {            tempPass[i] = 0;      }      return encrypted;}

html:
What to Check For

Ensure that encryption is used to protect all sensitive data transmitted over the network.

Why

Because network traffic can be easily eavesdropped or modified by attackers, passing sensitive data over the network is prone to a host of attacks, including data theft and data manipulation.

How to Check

When an application transmits sensitive data over the network, it is necessary to ensure that it is encrypted to protect the data from being read or modified in transit. To ensure this, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Search for hyperlinks leading to non-TLS resources. Review application code and look for hyperlinks starting with "http://" - such hyperlinks lead to resources, which are not secured by TLS. Make sure that non-TLS hyperlinks are not used to navigate between pages that handle sensitive data.

  2. Identify sensitive information. Sensitive data is any information that is kept secret and should be disclosed only to authorized parties. Common examples of sensitive data include, but are not limited to, names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card and other financial information, passwords and private keys. Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information. Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data. Sensitive data can be defined as follows:

    • Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with others.
    • Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application.
    • Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users

  3. Verify that sensitive data is securely transmitted. Ensure that your application transmits sensitive data in a secured fashion. Verify that your application encrypts the data using encryption or hashing and encrypts the communication link:

    • Encrypting application data: Your application securely transforms its application data before transmitting it over the network:

      • Hashing: Hashing is a one-way mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a non-retrievable way. If your application uses hashing as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:

        • Salt: Your application generates its salt using the SecureRandom class.
        • Function: Your application uses SHA-256, SHA-384 or SHA-512 as its hash function.
        • Invocation: Your application invokes the Cipher.doFinal method to perform the hashing procedure.
        • Clean-up: Your application securely cleans-up all instances of the sensitive data after the hashing procedure has been completed.

      • Encryption: Encryption is a mechanism for protecting sensitive data in a retrievable way. If your application uses encryption as means for protecting sensitive data, verify that the following pieces are in place:

        • Encryption Key: Your application's encryption keys are securely stored inside your application's key store. 
        • Function: Your application uses AES, 3DES, or any other strong symmetric encryption function.
        • Invocation: Your application invokes the Cipher.init and Cipher.doFinal methods to perform the encryption procedure.
        • Clean-up: Your application securely cleans-up all instances of the sensitive data and their encryption keys after the encryption procedure has been completed.

    • Encrypting the communication links: Check if your application's communication links are properly secured.

How to Fix

Use the following steps to protect sensitive data over the network:

  1. Identify sensitive information. Sensitive data is any information that is kept secret and should be disclosed only to authorized parties. Common examples of sensitive data include, but are not limited to, names of customers, government issued ID numbers, credit card and other financial information, passwords and private keys. Some industries, such as health care and banking, have regulatory standards that define sensitive information. Use regulatory requirements, as they apply to your application, to identify sensitive data. Sensitive data can be defined as follows:

    • Information that either contains personally identifiable information or can be used to derive personally identifiable information that should not be shared with others.
    • Information that a user provides that they would not want shared with other users of the application.
    • Information that comes from an external trusted source that is not designed to be shared with users.

  2. Choose an appropriate protection mechanism. Choosing the appropriate protection mechanism may depend on various conditions: purpose of the sensitive data, role of the other network party, infrastructure and supported technologies. Because sensitive data must be encrypted when in transit, there are two strategies, to encrypt the communication channel or to encrypt the application data:

    • Encrypt the communication channel: Depending on the current infrastructure and the other network party, it is possible to encrypt the connections using Java's crypto library or any technologies supported by the remote party.

    • Encrypt the application data: If your application's communication channels cannot be encrypted, encrypt the application data. Hashing or encryption should be used when protecting the application data. Use hashing if the application data will be used only for comparison purposes. Use encryption if the application data will be retrieved at a later stage.

      If hashing is used, choose a longer salt, 16 or more bits. In the case that the produced hash is compromised, longer salts make it more difficult for an attacker to gain access to the sensitive data. If your application uses randomly generated salt, make sure that your application encrypts the random salt and stores it into a configuration file. Always use SecureRandom and not Random to generate the salt. Example of using SecureRandom to generate a random salt:

      public static byte[] generateSalt() throws NoSuchAlgorithmException
      {
            // Note that salt is declared as private static byte[] and is
            // initialized to null.
            if (salt == null)
            {
                  SecureRandom srand = SecureRandom.getInstance("SHA1PRNG");
                                salt = new byte[4];
                  srand.nextBytes(salt);
            }
             return salt;
      }

      Choosing a strong hashing algorithm is also important. Stronger algorithms prevent multiple unique pieces of data from producing identical hash values. The current recommendation is to use SHA-256 or stronger.

      public String hashCredentials(char[] pass, byte[] salt)
            throws GeneralSecurityException, IOException
      {
            MessageDigest md;
            byte[] tempPass;
            byte[] digest;
                  md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-512");
            //Convert char[] to byte[]
            tempPass = new byte[pass.length];
            for (int i = 0; i < pass.length; i++)
            {
                  tempPass[i] = (byte)pass[i];
            }
            md.update(tempPass);
            md.update(salt);
            digest = md.digest();
            md.reset();
            //Clean tempPass
            for (int i = 0; i < tempPass.length; i++)
            {
                  tempPass[i] = 0;
            }
             return new String(digest);
      }

      Use encryption if the application data will be retrieved at a later stage.

      Use symmetric encryption if and only if your application is the only entity that will access the encrypted data. Use a key size of 265-bit or higher and AES for symmetric encryption.

      Use public/private key encryption if the data will be accessed by two or more parties. Use a key size of 2048-bit or higher and RSA for public/private key encryption. Public/private key encryption allows your application to share sensitive data with multiple entities without disclosing its own encryption key.

      // Because the following code generates a new encryption key,
      // make sure to store it into the application's keystore.
      KeyGenerator kgen = KeyGenerator.getInstance("AES");
      kgen.init(256);
      SecretKey skey = kgen.generateKey();
      // Set up cipherCipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");
      cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, skey);
      // Note that sensitiveData is of type byte[] and contains
      // data that is sensitive in naturebyte[] encrypted = cipher.doFinal(sensitiveData);

  3. Apply the appropriate protection mechanism. Evaluate the code and determine the places where sensitive data is transmitted. Apply the established protection mechanism at each location.

    try
    {
          // The application produces a hash based on the sensitive data
          userEmail = MyApp.getEmailForUser(user);
          passDigest = encryptCredentials(userEmail, pass, salt);
    }
    catch (GeneralSecurityException gse)
    {
          // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms
          return false;}catch (IOException ioe)
    {
          // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms
          return false;
    }
    // The application stores the hashed sensitive data into the database
    Connection cn = MyApp.getDBConnection();
    PreparedStatement st = cn.prepareStatement("select login_attempts from myappUsers"
                                            + " where user = ? and pass = ?;");
    st.setString(1, user);
    st.setBytes(2, passDigest);
    ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery();

Note: PCI DSS requirements state that all sensitive data must be encrypted before being sent over the network or be sent over an encrypted channel.

Problem Example

The following code authenticates a user based on a username and password. The supplied credentials are compared to the credentials stored in the backend database. Unfortunately, the credentials are transmitted in plaintext and could be stolen if the network is compromised.

public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass)
{
      // Query the credential store with the provided credentials
      ...
}

Solution Example

The following code validates the user based on a given username and password. It uses the user's valid email address and a random salt to encrypt the user's password before comparing the username and the produced digest against the data stored in the backend database. Therefore, the password is encrypted before being transmitted over the network and is protected from being compromised.

public boolean validateUser(String user, char[] pass)
{
       ...
       // Encrypt the credentials
      try
      {
            userEmail = MyApp.getEmailForUser(user);
            passDigest = encryptCredentials(userEmail, pass, salt);
      }
      catch (GeneralSecurityException gse)
      {
            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms
            return false;
      }
     catch (IOException ioe)
      {
            // Add the appropriate logging and exception handling mechanisms
            return false;
      }
       // Query the credential store and execute the rest of the authentication steps
      ...
}
public static byte[] encryptCredentials(String email, char[] pass, byte[] salt)
      throws GeneralSecurityException, IOException
{
      MessageDigest md; 
      byte[] tempPass;
      byte[] rawKey;
      // Generate encryption key
      md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-512");
      md.update(email.getBytes("UTF-8"));
      md.update(salt);
      rawKey = md.digest();
      md.reset();
      SecretKeySpec skeySpec = new SecretKeySpec(rawKey, "AES");
      // Set up cipher
      Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");
      cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, skeySpec);
      // Convert char[] to byte[]
      tempPass = new byte[pass.length];
      for (int i = 0; i < pass.length; i++)
      {
            tempPass[i] = (byte)pass[i];
      }
      // Encrypt password
      byte[] encrypted = cipher.doFinal(tempPass);
            //Clean tempPass
      for (int i = 0; i < tempPass.length; i++)
      {
            tempPass[i] = 0;
      }
      return encrypted;
}
